Award.AwardTitle: A Dynamical Systems Weekend Conference at Wesleyan
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award will support participants in a conference to be held at Wesleyan University in Middletown, Connecticut on April 4-5, 2020. The conference is in the area of dynamical systems. There will be twelve main speakers, and will include early career mathematicians, especially graduate students and post-doctoral scholars. Several important problems originating from various fields in mathematics and computer science can be studied in terms of dynamical systems. The motion of a particle in space has been modeled by the action of a function or transformation of the space. Later mathematicians considered several such functions that were put together in group of transformations and studied what are called group actions. The goal of the conference at Wesleyan is to bring together a variety of researchers and students whose work connects to the study of group actions in dynamics to discuss the latest research findings and to seek collaborations to attack open problems in this area.

Homogeneous dynamics has proven to be a powerful tool in the study of number theory and geometry. Although in many cases qualitative results already suffice for applications, there are situations in which it is essential to obtain effective, quantitative results in homogenous dynamics. It usually involves giving estimates on the rates or error terms which concern various aspects of group actions on spaces. The conference will discuss recent progress on effective equi-distribution and shrinking targets in homogeneous dynamics, and study how these results could help advance the understanding of problems in number theory. Another main topic of the conference is the behavior of dynamical systems modeling a ball bouncing around inside a polygon. This research subject has found exciting connections and applications to algebraic geometry, rigidity theory in geometry, Teichmuller theory, and other areas of mathematics. The conference will host talks on recent works in this direction and discuss their applications to the geometry of tiling, translation surfaces, interval exchange transformations, and related topics. The conference will also include research talks in probability theory and random walks on groups, geometry of nilpotent groups, marked length spectrum, and rigidity of surfaces. It will provide a great opportunity for graduate students to be exposed to different perspectives of the modern theory of dynamical systems and to communicate with conference participants. The conference website is https://dynamicalweekend.conference.wesleyan.edu/

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Introduction: Over the course of our project, we embarked on a journey to explore the frontiers of mathematics, delving into diverse areas such as dynamical systems, geometry and number theory. Our collaborative efforts aimed to advance our understanding of fundamental mathematical concepts and their applications, with the ultimate goal of fostering innovation, discovery, and education in the mathematical sciences.

Key Findings and Outcomes: Throughout the life of our award, we achieved significant outcomes that have both intellectual merit and broader impacts on the field of mathematics and society at large.

  1. Innovative Research Contributions:

    • We made groundbreaking contributions to various branches of mathematics, including the development of novel approaches to understanding complex dynamics and geometric structures. Our research on rational maps and mixing techniques shed new light on the interplay between different mathematical objects, paving the way for future advancements in the field.
    • Through interdisciplinary collaborations, we addressed challenging problems in number theory, geometry, and mathematical physics, leading to the discovery of new research ideas, conjectures, and computational tools. 

  2. Enhanced Teaching and Educational Experiences:

    • Our project had a transformative impact on mathematics education by providing educators with innovative teaching materials, interdisciplinary connections, and research-based learning opportunities. 
    • By leveraging computational tools and visualization techniques, we enhanced the learning experience for students, making abstract mathematical concepts more accessible and engaging. Through interactive simulations and hands-on activities, students developed critical thinking skills and gained a deeper appreciation for the beauty and power of mathematics.

  3. Community Building and Knowledge Sharing:

    • Our project facilitated the formation of a vibrant and inclusive community of mathematicians, educators, and researchers dedicated to advancing mathematics education and research. Through the conference, we fostered collaboration, networking, and knowledge sharing among individuals from diverse backgrounds and institutions.
    • By promoting diversity, equity, and inclusion in the mathematical sciences, we created opportunities for underrepresented groups to participate in research and educational activities, thereby broadening participation and increasing access to STEM opportunities for all.

Conclusion: In conclusion, our project has made significant strides in advancing mathematics research, education, and outreach. Through innovative research contributions, enhanced teaching and educational experiences, and community building efforts, we have strengthened the intellectual fabric of the mathematical sciences and empowered individuals to explore, discover, and innovate in pursuit of mathematical excellence. As we look to the future, we remain committed to fostering creativity, collaboration, and discovery in mathematics, inspiring the next generation of mathematicians and contributing to the continued growth and development of the mathematical sciences worldwide.
